definition: Evidence, often personal, that is collected casually rather than by a well-designed study
A group we are interested in studying. 'Population' often refers to a group of people, but the term is used for other subjects, too
A study that collects data about a population at a particular point in time
In a repeated cross-sectional study, each repetition of the study is called a cycle
A study that follows a population over time, collecting data from the same group repeatedly
In a dataset, a collection of information about a single person or other subject
A person who responds to a survey
The subset of a population used to collect data
A sample is representative if every member of the population has the same chance of being in the sample
The technique of increasing the representation of a sub-population in order to avoid errors due to small sample sizes
Values collected and recorded with little or no checking, calculation or interpretation
A value that is generated by calculation and other logic applied to raw data
Processes that include validating data, identifying errors, translating between data types and representations, etc.
The values that appear in a sample and the frequency of each
A mapping from values to frequencies, or a graph that shows this mapping
The number of times a value appears in a sample
The most frequent value in a sample, or one of the most frequent values
An idealization of a bell-shaped distribution; also known as a Gaussian distribution
A distribution in which all values have the same frequency
The part of a distribution at the high and low extremes
A characteristic of a sample or population; intuitively, it is an average or typical value
A value far from the central tendency
A measure of how spread out the values in a distribution are
A statistic that quantifies some aspect of a distribution, like central tendency or spread
A summary statistic often used to quantify spread
The square root of variance, also used as a measure of spread
A summary statistic intended to quantify the size of an effect like a difference between groups
A result, like a difference between groups, that is relevant in practice.
a representation of a distribution as a function that maps from values to probabilities
A frequency expressed as a fraction of the sample size
The process of dividing a frequency by a sample size to get a probability
In a pandas DataFrame, the index is a special column that contains the row labels
The percentage of values in a distribution that are less than or equal to a given value
The value associated with a given percentile rank
A function that maps from values to their cumulative probabilities. $\mathrm{CDF}(x)$ is the fraction of the sample less than or equal to $x$
A function that maps from a cumulative probability, $p$, to the corresponding value
The 50th percentile, often used as a measure of central tendency
The difference between the 75th and 25th percentiles, used as a measure of spread
A sequence of values that correspond to equally spaced percentile ranks; for example, the quartiles of a distribution are the 25th, 50th and 75th percentiles

A property of a sampling process. 'With replacement' means that the same value can be chosen more than once; 'without replacement' means that once a value is chosen, it is removed from the population.
The distribution of values in a sample
A distribution whose CDF is an analytic function
A useful simplification. Analytic distributions are often good models of more complex empirical distributions
The elapsed time between two events
A function that maps from a value, $x$, to the fraction of values that exceed $x$, which is $1 - \mathrm{CDF}(x)$
The normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1
A plot of the values in a sample versus random values from a standard normal distribution
The derivative of a continuous CDF, a function that maps a value to its probability density
A quantity that can be integrated over a range of values to yield a probability. If the values are in units of cm, for example, probability density is in units of probability per cm
An algorithm that estimates a PDF based on a sample
To approximate a continuous function or distribution with a discrete function. The opposite of smoothing
A statistic based on the sum of data raised to a power
A statistic based on deviation from the mean, raised to a power
A ratio of moments that has no units
A measure of how asymmetric a distribution is
A moment-based statistic intended to quantify the skewness of a distribution
A statistic intended to quantify the skewness of a distribution based on the median, mean, and standard deviation
A statistic is robust if it is relatively immune to the effect of outliers.
A visualization of the relationship between two variables, showing one point for each row of data
Random noise added to data for purposes of visualization
Loss of information when multiple points are plotted on top of each other
A statistic that measures the strength of the relationship between two variables
To transform a set of values so that their mean is 0 and their variance is 1
A value that has been standardized so that it is expressed in standard deviations from the mean
A measure of the tendency of two variables to vary together
The index where an element appears in a sorted list
An experimental design in which subjects are divided into groups at random, and different groups are given different treatments
A group in a controlled trial that receives some kind of intervention
A group in a controlled trial that receives no treatment, or a treatment whose effect is known
An experimental design that takes advantage of a natural division of subjects into groups in ways that are at least approximately random.
The process of inferring the parameters of a distribution from a sample
A statistic used to estimate a parameter
A measure of estimation error
The square root of MSE, a more meaningful representation of typical error magnitude
An estimator that computes the point estimate most likely to be correct
The tendency of an estimator to be above or below the actual value of the parameter, when averaged over repeated experiments
Error in an estimate due to the limited size of the sample and variation due to chance
Error in an estimate due to a sampling process that is not representative of the population
Error in an estimate due to inaccuracy collecting or recording data
The distribution of a statistic if an experiment is repeated many times
The RMSE of an estimate, which quantifies variability due to sampling error (but not other sources of error)
An interval that represents the expected range of an estimator if an experiment is repeated many times.
The process of determining whether an apparent effect is statistically significant
A statistic used to quantify an effect size
A model of a system based on the assumption that an apparent effect is due to chance
The probability that an effect could occur by chance
An effect is statistically significant if it is unlikely to occur by chance
A way to compute p-values by generating permutations of an observed dataset
A way to compute p-values by generating samples, with replacement, from an observed dataset
A test that asks, 'What is the chance of an effect as big as the observed effect, positive or negative?'
A test that asks, 'What is the chance of an effect as big as the observed effect, and with the same sign?'
A test that uses the chi-squared statistic as the test statistic
The conclusion that an effect is real when it is not
The conclusion that an effect is due to chance when it is not
The probability of a positive test if the null hypothesis is false
a line intended to model the relationship between variables
A model of a dataset that minimizes the sum of squares of the residuals
The deviation of an actual value from a model
A measure of how well a model fits data
A statistic intended to quantify goodness of fit
A value associated with an observation in a sample that indicates what part of the population it represents.
One of several related processes for estimating parameters that fit a model to data
The variables in a regression model we would like to predict. Also known as endogenous variables
The variables used to predict or explain the dependent variables. Also known as independent, or exogenous, variables
A regression with only one dependent and one explanatory variable
A regression with multiple explanatory variables, but only one dependent variable
A regression based on a linear model
A linear regression that estimates parameters by minimizing the squared error of the residuals
A relationship between two variables that is caused by a statistical artifact or a factor, not included in the model, that is related to both variables
A variable included in a regression to eliminate or 'control for' a spurious relationship
A variable that contributes information to a regression model indirectly because of a relationship with another factor, so it acts as a proxy for that factor
A variable that can have one of a discrete set of unordered values
An operation that combines data from two DataFrames using a key to match up rows in the two frames
An approach to finding relationships between variables by testing a large number of models
A form of regression used when the dependent variable is boolean
A form of regression used when the dependent variable is a non-negative integer, usually a count
An alternative way of representing a probability, P, as the ratio of the probability and its complement, P / (1-P).
column4: A dataset where each value is associated with a timestamp, often a series of measurements and the times they were collected

definition: A sequence of consecutive values in a time series, often used to compute a moving average
One of several statistics intended to estimate the underlying trend in a time series by computing averages (of some kind) for a series of overlapping windows
A moving average based on the mean value in each window
A moving average based on a weighted mean that gives the highest weight to the most recent values, and exponentially decreasing weights to earlier values
A parameter of EWMA (exponentially-weighted moving average) that determines how quickly the weights decrease
Correlation between a time series and a shifted or lagged version of itself
The size of the shift in a serial correlation or autocorrelation
A more general term for a serial correlation with any amount of lag
A function that maps from lag to serial correlation
A model is stationary if the parameters and the distribution of residuals does not change over time
A set of methods for describing and predicting lifetimes, or more generally time until an event occurs
A function that maps from a time, $t$, to the probability of surviving past $t$
A function that maps from $t$ to the fraction of people alive until $t$ who die at $t$
An algorithm for estimating hazard and survival functions
a group of subjects defined by an event, like date of birth, in a particular interval of time
a difference between cohorts
A property of expected remaining lifetime, 'New better than used in expectation.'
A property of expected remaining lifetime, 'Used better than new in expectation.'
